item.description:
Actually there are no moose or mooses involved in this hike. And, we're not going to Hell. But, it will be a helluva hike conceived in the mnd of our beloved but torture-prone Karen. It's a 9.5 mile hike that loops over or past 5 mountain peaks - 4 of which are 4,000 footers. Actually the elevation gain is not too bad. The trail head is at 2,400' and the highest peak is at 4,802'. So, after you add in some for the usual ups and downs you end up with close to 3,000 verical feel in about 7.5 hours.

NOTE: Likely expanded attendance or second section since this hike filled up so fast.

The western most white mountain peak over 4,000 ft is Moosilauke (4,802',) our ultimate quest. However, we'll need to do some work before enjoying the bald mountain-top views. The name Moosilauke means "a bald place" not mooses. FYI - With almost all of the land in this area owned by Dartmouth College these trails, including the Appalachian Trail, is maintained by the Dartmouth Outing Club. 

In a perfect world we'll do the following:

Start at the trailhead at the end of the Ravine Lodge Road 

Follow the George Brook Trail for 0.2 miles

Take a sharp right onto the Asquam-Ridge Trail for 3.9 miles

Continue on the Beaver Brook Trail 1.9 miles to the summit of Mt. Moosilauke (4,802') (we'll be on the Appalachian Trail throughout this section)

Continue southwest on the Moosilauke Carriage Road for 0.9 to the summit of South Peak (4,523.)

Continue on the Moosilauke Carriage Road for 1.2 miles

Turn left/northeast on the Snapper Trail for 1.1 miles

Rejoin the George Brook Trail to the parking lot for 0.3 miles (wow that's a lot!)

 

The peaks that I did not mention above - Mt. Waternomee (3,940') and Mt. Blue (4,529) are off the trail with no cut trails to the summits. The Mt. Jim summit (4,172) is just a few yards off the trail. For you home gamers only Moosilauke is included in the list of 48 4,000+  footers in New Hampshire.

Getting there from Providence:

Take Route 95 to route 93 north

Exit 32 is the Kancamangus Highway exit - Go west on route 112. Bear left onto route 118. Drive on that for a long time. You may see a sign for Moosilauke Ravine Lodge. Take right onto Ravine Lodge Road. Drive until you can't drive any more. Park. Get ready to rumble!

We NEED to start hiking at 10:00 AM so arrive early to gear up. Allow 3.5 hours drive minimum from PVD.

Overnight Option: After this hike I'll be unfit to drive after crawling to the nearest beer tap, so consider an overnight option. Lot's of hotels by Loon Mtn and I'll check on the camping options. And, because I enjoy self abuse so much I'll be ready for another hike (TBD) or something else on Sunday. After a 40 lb breakfast of course.

Mandatory Equipment List: 
This list could change based on trail conditions just prior to the hike. 

  • Synthetic shirt and waterproof pants. No cotton. No jeans. 
  • Wool/ synthetic socks.
  • Sturdy Hiking Boots suitable for uneven terrain. 
  • Rain / Wind Jacket with hood. No Ponchos. 
  • Warm fleece layer. 
  • Warm fleece outer layer or wool hat (It can be pretty windy on ridge to the Moose.) 
  • Sunglasses and sun screen.
  • 3 liters Water
  • Headlamp 
  • Spare Lithium batteries for Headlamp. Bring Lithium, not Alkaline batteries. 
  • Trail Snacks 
  • Lunch
  • Your attorney's (no, just kidding. Checking to see if you're reading this stuff.) 

No Jeans, Sneakers, or Cotton clothing on the hike! 

Car Pooling Recommended: Use the comments section to find travel mates.

Guests: If a member wants to bring a guest please contact me via my email.

Liability Waiver

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree tothe following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associatedwith this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: Dead end of Ravine Lodge Road (1.6 miles north of NH 118. Silver Subaru RI 6730)
item.name: Moose Hike from Hell
